text.p: - Slovenia attends a two-day meeting of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. Unofficial estimates are that Slovenia's macroeconomic position is quite favourable but it still has a lot of work to do with restructuring of its banks and tax reforms.

- The parliament will vote on the new government line-up on Thursday after all 10 new ministerial candidates passed parliamentary hearings. Eight candidates from the previous line-up did not have to go through the hearings again.

- The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development will increase a loan to Slovenian curtain maker Julon to $31.6 million from $19.7 million in order to increase the company's competitiveness abroad.
- In 1996 Slovenia earned $1.21 billion from tourism, a 12 percent increase from the previous year, the Chamber of Economy said.
- Slovenian ski maker Elan will not be sold to the Italian group Benetton, executive vice president of Elan said on Tuesday, after rumours that Benetton is buying Elan were spread.

- Weekly papers of Slovenian minority in Austria Nas Tednik and Slovenski Vestnik on Tuesday received threatening letters from a neo-Nazi organisation. The two papers were already threatened by similar letters in November and December 1996.
- Listed food producer Kolinska said that its 1996 net profit fell 13 percent to 560 million tolars ($3.7 million).
- Slovenian unemployment in January rose 1.5 percent compared to December 1996 and 0.5 percent compared to January 1995, the unemployment office said.
